required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Fatigability of Lower Limb Muscle in Older Adults: Protective Effects of Strength Training Exercise in Old Men and Women
clinical_study.official_title: Fatigability of Limb Muscle in Older Adults: Protective Effects of Exercise

brief_summary.textblock:
The primary goal is to determine the mechanisms of fatigue in older (>70 yrs) men and women from dynamic contractions with a secondary goal of testing a novel and potentially translational exercise-training program designed to protect muscle performance during dynamic activities. The following specific aims and hypotheses will be tested:
Aim 1. Determine the extent to which fiber function, the cross-bridge mechanism of muscle fatigue, and the economy of contraction differ in fast (type IIa and IIx) and slow (type I) fibers in young and older (>70 yrs) men and women. Hypothesis 1. Slow type I and fast type II fiber peak isometric force (kN/M2), maximal shortening velocity (V0), and Ca2+ sensitivity are well maintained, but peak power and the transition from the low- to high-force state (ktr) are compromised in older adults especially women. Hypothesis 2. The economy of slow and fast fiber contraction declines in the older adults as reflected by a higher myofibrillar ATPase rate per tension developed. Hypothesis 3. Under fatigue conditions (low pH and high inorganic phosphate), slow and fast fibers from older adults show greater inhibition of maximal shortening velocity (V0) and peak power and decline in economy than fibers from young adults. Hypothesis 4. Aging reduces the content and phosphorylation of myosin binding protein C and myosin light chain 2 and the fraction of myosin heads in the ordered array.
Aim 2. Determine the susceptibility of older (>70 yrs) men and women to fatigue induced by dynamic contractions. Young and old men and women will perform dynamic fatiguing contractions with the knee extensor muscles. Peripheral and central fatigue will be quantified using transcranial magnetic stimulation (TMS). Hypothesis 1. With dynamic contractions older men and women (>70 yrs) fatigue more rapidly than young adults. Hypothesis 2. The increased fatigability in older adults is not caused by greater central fatigue than in the young.
Aim 3. Determine the effectiveness of dynamic exercise training using velocities of contractions known to generate peak power. Older adults will perform 12 weeks training to determine the efficacy of this novel training. Before and after training the following will be assessed: fatigue during dynamic contractions, central and peripheral fatigue with TMS, whole muscle metabolism with magnetic resonance spectroscopy (MRS), magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) and single fiber function and fatigue of fibers from muscle biopsies. Hypothesis 1. Training at velocities known to elicit peak power (~ 30% of V0) will improve whole muscle and body performance, muscle fiber size and function in older adults to a greater extent than traditional high resistant contractions.

study_design_info.intervention_model_description: All participants will participate in 8 weeks of leg extension exercise training (3 days per week) to determine the efficacy of slow velocity but low load resistance training exercise on one leg compared with traditional fast velocity and high load resistance training on the other leg. Before and after training the following will be assessed: fatigue of the lower limb muscles during 4-minutes dynamic contractions, neural and muscular fatigue using electrical stimulation of the muscles and TMS, whole muscle metabolism with magnetic resonance spectroscopy (MRS), magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) to assess muscle volume and single fiber function and fatigue from fiber taken from muscle biopsies.

primary_outcome.measure: Changes in 1 RM (One Repetition Maximum) after 8 weeks resistance training
primary_outcome.time_frame: 1 RM was assessed on a weekly basis and the loads adjusted accordingly for the 8 weeks resistance training and before and 3-days after completion of training.
primary_outcome.description: 1 RM is the greatest weight achieved through the full range of motion

primary_outcome.measure: Changes in Maximum voluntary contraction (MVC) force after 8 weeks resistance training
primary_outcome.time_frame: Before and 3-days after completion of resistance training intervention of 8 weeks.
primary_outcome.description: MVC is the greatest force generated by isometric contraction.

primary_outcome.measure: Changes in Knee Extensor Power Curve after 8 weeks resistance training
primary_outcome.time_frame: Before and 4-days after completion of resistance training intervention of 8 weeks.
primary_outcome.description: Strength (force and torque) and power (velocity) of the knee extensors are while the participant is seated in a Biodex System 4 Pro dynamometer (Biodex, NY) and recorded on line via a Power 1401 to Spike2 software [(CED), UK] for later analysis

primary_outcome.measure: Changes in Fatigability after 8 weeks resistance training
primary_outcome.time_frame: Before and 3-days after completion of resistance training intervention of 8 weeks.
primary_outcome.description: Participants are verbally cued to kick once every 3 s for a total of 4 min (80 contractions). The low frequency of contractions was selected to maximize muscle perfusion during the exercise by inducing a low duty cycle.

primary_outcome.measure: Changes in Central (Supraspinal) and Peripheral Fatigue after 8 weeks resistance training
primary_outcome.time_frame: Before and 3-days after completion of resistance training intervention of 8 weeks.
primary_outcome.description: Central and peripheral fatigue are quantified using Transcranial magnetic stimulation (TMS) and electrical stimulation during MVCs and submaximal contractions of the knee extensor muscles. Central fatigue is quantified as the reduction in voluntary activation. Supraspinal fatigue is a component of central fatigue and is quantified as the reduction of voluntary activation calculated from forces evoked via stimulation at the motor cortex. Peripheral fatigue of whole muscle is quantified as the amplitude of the superimposed twitch and its rate of change in relaxation. This can be reliably achieved with TMS.

primary_outcome.measure: Changes in Muscle activity after 8 weeks resistance training
primary_outcome.time_frame: Before and 3-days after completion of resistance training intervention of 8 weeks
primary_outcome.description: The Electromyography (EMG) activity of agonist muscles (vastus lateralis, vastus medialis, rectus femoris) and antagonist muscles (hamstrings) will be recorded with bipolar surface electrodes placed over the muscle.

primary_outcome.measure: Changes in Single muscle fiber function after 8 weeks resistance training
primary_outcome.time_frame: Before and 10-days after completion of resistance training intervention of 8 weeks.
primary_outcome.description: Muscle Biopsies: An area of vastus lateralis will numbed by injection with local anesthetic. A small 1/4 inch incision will be made in the skin and a needle inserted briefly into the muscle to remove a piece of muscle about the size of a pencil eraser. The incision is pulled closed with a bandage and the area over the incision will be covered with an elastic pressure bandage. The whole muscle biopsy procedure will take a total of approximately 15 minutes, with the actual biopsy lasting only a few seconds. The biopsy samples will be stored for analyses and used to examine various aspects of skeletal muscle health.

primary_outcome.measure: Changes in muscle volume of the quadricep muscles after 8 weeks resistance training
primary_outcome.time_frame: Before and 2-days after completion of resistance training intervention of 8 weeks.
primary_outcome.description: Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) is used to detect the muscle volume and serial cross-sections of muscle.

primary_outcome.measure: Changes in muscle metabolism while the participant performs fatiguing knee extensor exercise after 8 weeks resistance training
primary_outcome.time_frame: Before and 2-days after completion of resistance training intervention of 8 weeks.
primary_outcome.description: Phosphorus magnetic resonance spectroscopy (P-MRS) is used to noninvasively measure or calculate intracellular ATP, ADP, phosphocreatine (PCr), inorganic phosphate (Pi), and pH in the quadriceps of participants.

secondary_outcome.measure: Changes in functional endurance using the lower limb muscles after 8 weeks resistance training
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Before and 2-days after completion of resistance training intervention of 8 weeks.
secondary_outcome.description: 6-Minute Walk test assesses functional endurance using the lower limb muscles.

secondary_outcome.measure: Changes in functional strength, balance and agility using the lower limb muscles after 8 weeks resistance training
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Before and 2-days after completion of resistance training intervention of 8 weeks.
secondary_outcome.description: Stair-Climbing test accesses functional strength, balance and agility through climbing a set of number of steps.

secondary_outcome.measure: Changes in functional strength, transitional movements, balance using lower limb muscles after 8 weeks resistance training
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Before and 2-days after completion of resistance training intervention of 8 weeks.
secondary_outcome.description: Sit-to-stand endurance test access functional strength, transitional movements, balance using lower limb muscles

secondary_outcome.measure: Changes in balance ability after 8 weeks resistance training
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Before and 2-days after completion of resistance training intervention of 8 weeks.
secondary_outcome.description: The Berg Balance Scale (BBS) was developed to measure balance among older people with impairment in balance function by assessing the performance of functional tasks. Description: 14-item scale designed to measure balance of the older adult in a clinical setting. Equipment needed: Ruler, two standard chairs (one with arm rests, one without), footstool or step, stopwatch or wristwatch, 15 ft walkway. Completion: Time: 15-20 minutes Scoring: A five-point scale, ranging from 0-4. "0" indicates the lowest level of function and "4" the highest level of function. Total Score = 56 Interpretation: 41-56 = low fall risk, 21-40 = medium fall risk, 0 -20 = high fall risk A change of 8 points is required to reveal a genuine change in function between 2 assessments.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: The MAQ is measured only at the pre-training sessions before resistance training intervention of 8 weeks.
secondary_outcome.description: This measure provides the usual level of physical activity of the study participants. Modifiable Physical Activity Questionnaire (MAQ) estimates the relative kilo-calorie expenditure of energy per week based on a 12-month recall of occupational and leisure physical activity. Both leisure and occupational activities are weighted by the relative intensity as a MET (Metabolic equivalents: 1 MET = energy expenditure at rest) hours per week (MET∙h∙wk-1) (reference: PubMed ID: 16672833).

secondary_outcome.time_frame: The step per day is measured only at the pre-training sessions before resistance training intervention of 8 weeks.
secondary_outcome.description: The physical activity of each participant is quantified using a tri-axial accelerometry (GT3X, ActiGraph). The participants wear the accelerator for 4 days (2 weekdays and 2 weekend days) which estimates and tracks the steps over the course of 4 days (reference: PubMed ID: 18364517 and 21798044)

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Before and 2-days after completion of resistance training intervention of 8 weeks.
secondary_outcome.description: The height of each participant is measured using the standard wall-mounted height rod.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Before and 2-days after completion of resistance training intervention of 8 weeks.
secondary_outcome.description: The weight of each participant is measured using the standard digital weight scale.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Before and 2-days after completion of resistance training intervention of 8 weeks.
secondary_outcome.description: Height and weight are combined to report BMI in kg/m^2. Measured height (meter) and weight (kg) are added in the participant information in the software for the Dual Energy X-ray Absorptiometry (DXA) to yield the accurate BMI value. DXA is also used for accessing the lean mass (%total mass) and fat mass (%total mass) for each participant.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Measured before and after resistance training intervention of 8 weeks.
secondary_outcome.description: Measurement of resting and peak forearm blood flow, throughout and immediate after the resistance training.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Before and immediately after Dynamic fatiguing contractions (outcome 4) and 6-Min Walk test (outcome 10) at the pre- and post-training sessions, immediately after completion (4th set) of each resistance training regime during 8 weeks intervention.
secondary_outcome.description: An index of perceived effort is accessed with the modified Borg 10-point scale. The participants were instructed to focus the assessment of effort on the quadriceps muscles performing the task. 0 is the resting state and 10 is the strongest contraction.

arm_group.description: Low-load and Low-velocity resistance training: Each set of contractions will involve a load at 30% 1RM with a steady 6 second-lift (shortening or concentric phase) followed by a 6 second-lowering (lengthening or eccentric phase) of the weight.
High-load and High-velocity resistance training: Each set of contractions will involve a load to achieve 8 repetition maximum (RM) with 1 second to lift followed by 1 second to lower the weight

intervention.description: • Participant performed 4 sets of 8 repetition of two different resistance training regimes. Participant visit 3 days per week for 8 weeks period.

reference.citation: Kriska AM, Edelstein SL, Hamman RF, Otto A, Bray GA, Mayer-Davis EJ, Wing RR, Horton ES, Haffner SM, Regensteiner JG. Physical activity in individuals at risk for diabetes: Diabetes Prevention Program. Med Sci Sports Exerc. 2006 May;38(5):826-32.

Tudor-Locke C, Bassett DR Jr, Rutherford WJ, Ainsworth BE, Chan CB, Croteau K, Giles-Corti B, Le Masurier G, Moreau K, Mrozek J, Oppert JM, Raustorp A, Strath SJ, Thompson D, Whitt-Glover MC, Wilde B, Wojcik JR. BMI-referenced cut points for pedometer-determined steps per day in adults. J Phys Act Health. 2008;5 Suppl 1:S126-39.

Tudor-Locke C, Craig CL, Aoyagi Y, Bell RC, Croteau KA, De Bourdeaudhuij I, Ewald B, Gardner AW, Hatano Y, Lutes LD, Matsudo SM, Ramirez-Marrero FA, Rogers LQ, Rowe DA, Schmidt MD, Tully MA, Blair SN. How many steps/day are enough? For older adults and special populations. Int J Behav Nutr Phys Act. 2011 Jul 28;8:80. doi: 10.1186/1479-5868-8-80. Review.
